dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Good afternoon. How much does this shirt cost?

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Sí, esta otra está más barata — quince dólares.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Yes, this other one is cheaper — fifteen dollars.

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Gracias. Aquí tiene su cambio — cinco dólares.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Thank you. Here's your change — five dollars.

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: Puerto Rico uses US dollars (dólares), not pesos. Prices are quoted in dollars and cents. Bargaining is not typical in formal shops — prices are generally fixed. At flea markets (pulgas) or informal vendors, some negotiation may be possible.
cultural_notes_overrides.gestures: In Puerto Rico, shopping culture is influenced by both US retail norms and Latin American market traditions. Malls are very popular — Plaza Las Américas in San Juan is one of the largest in the Caribbean.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: 'El chavito' or 'chavo' means a small coin (penny/cent). 'Está en oferta' (it's on sale) and '2x1' promotions are heavily advertised. Credit and debit cards are universally accepted in most PR establishments.
